comment.author: 27442865@N08
comment._content: The date could not be 1902 because Luna Park hadn't opened yet.

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Thanks sweinstein99, good point. We go with the information on the negative envelopes until research points us elsewhere. I found a ref to the "Fire and Flames shown in this photo that dates it to 1904: Another illusion designed and staged by Thompson in 1904 was called Fire and Flames. It had its auditorium arranged that spectators were seated on the other side of the street from a burning four story building. Luna hired hundreds of firemen to fight imaginary flames. A rescue squad arrived to save men and women trapped in the building's top floors, who then jumped to safety into the nets below. Luna was the first park to present a live spectacular show, just barely beating Dreamland's similar show by weeks. We'll go with that (though it could certainly have been restaged in later years as well). Thanks, Deb Wythe Digital Lab

comment.author: 65892239@N08
comment._content: This is wonderful.  My great grandfather moved his family to 2202 Surf Ave where he opened a barber shop sometime between 1910 and 1912, this was their world.  Thanks for posting.  Is there anyway I could buy a copy?

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:

Hi BrokenLandStyle,
Glad you like the pic and thanks for letting us know about the family connection! You're welcome to go ahead and download and print the image if our full-size image is big enough for you. If you'd like a cleaned up, full-size, publication-quality TIFF, you can contact our Image Services person at reproductions@brooklynmuseum.org--we charge for those to support our program.
